Use of previously collected human biological samples
Non-clinical activities with staff, such as interviews, questionnaires or observation

Non-clinical activities with people, such as non-clinical assessments, observations or care procedures

identifying, developing, or prioritising the research question
being a member of a research advisory or reference group
being a member of the Trial Management Group or Data Monitoring Committee
developing the research methods (for example, designing questionnaires, or defining endpoints or outcome measures)
ensuring that the design of the research is feasible from the perspective of the participants (for example, identifying potential emotional or practical obstacles for research participants)
designing the inclusion and exclusion criteria including consideration of the demographic diversity of the study population
developing the risk or benefit analysis (for example, identifying and evaluating the probable risks and burden involved for research participants)
developing the recruitment and consent process (for example, how and when to approach potential participants)
developing participant information sheets, the consent forms, and other documents which are used to communicate with potential research participants
developing or delivering training to staff
developing the dissemination plan for the research
planning to attend the Research Ethics Committee meetings to help explain how and why the research design is likely to be acceptable to research participants
patients, service users or their carers, or members of the public have not been involved
we have existing arrangements in our organisation or team for involving patients, carers, service users or members of the public
we asked an existing patient and public involvement group external to our organisation or team (for example, run by an NHS Trust, university, charity, local councils)

we set up a new arrangement to involve patients, carers, service users or members of the public in our project (for example, posted the opportunity on the People in Research website, local noticeboards, or through a community organisation)
we were approached by some patients, carers, service users, a patient group, or a charity with a suggestion for this research and we have worked with them to develop it
being a member of research advisory or reference group
carrying out research activities (for example, facilitating focus groups, interviewing or administering questionnaires)
contributing to further regulatory submissions (such as amendments)
sharing research results (for example, by presenting at conferences or disseminating the research findings via social media)
developing plain language summaries of the results
there is no plan to involve public contributors in the remaining stages of the research process
case series or case note review
designing, developing or testing an AI product or tool

only adults with capacity to consent for themselves as participants
only adults lacking capacity to consent for themselves

Consent will not be obtained from any participants

Consent will not be obtained for the use of non-identifiable data or samples
Consent will not be obtained for access to data by the usual care team

The participant would be withdrawn from the project. Identifiable data or tissue already collected with consent would be retained and used. No further data or tissue would be collected or any other research procedures carried out on or in relation to the participant.
The participant would continue to be included in the project.
Not applicable - informed consent will not be sought from any participants in this project.
